Renmrks. 1t appears from the foregoing. among

JOHN SERGEANT, Esq. a decided friend cf the
Administration was elected member to Congress,
on Tuesday last, in Philadelphia. His opponent
was Joseph Hemphill Esq. decided Jacksonian.
Mr. Scrgeants majority was l56 votes.

As specimen Of the meetings. now holding in
Virginia, in opposition to General Jackson, we lay
before our readers those of Spotsylyania.

/. The General, in his Carter Beverly letter,
above quoted, makes it g early IN January 1895 !"
and in his Address to the Public, dated July, 10,
1927, he makes it in January 1885, rather more
safe period Of time, though not quite so precise.


g. Mr.. Buchanan, from letters which he wrote on
three days, Dec. 30, and 81 1924, and January 2,
1926, which letters he has probably since seen,
s' fixes the time" of his conversation on the Hirtleth
day Of December, 1924.


3. Mr.. Eatonsays that Mr. Buchanan talked with
him on the 9Th or 10Th Of Jam 1925, and then had
his interview with the General on the snext day
viz. on the 9th or Goth.


Now here seems to be some little difference be-
tween the " 30h December, 1894, early in JAN
uary," 'sn January" and the g 9th or Goth jan
uary 1926" Who's right and whose wrong
Mr.. Buchanan declares that he had but one con-
versation, prior to the election, and we have seen
three several periods mentioned at which it took
place, with difference of three weeks between the
time specified by Mr.. Buchanan and Mr.. Eaton
Both are quite sure as to the time, but both cannot
be right.


If there are such errors as to time, when one
fixes the precise day, another makes it early and
then sem January, and another the 18th OF goth
January, 1895, it is not difficult to believe that in
their statements there are


Some other differences.


Let us see. Mr. Eaton says BY the showing of
Mr.. lsaacks and Mr. Buchanan, it now appears, that
Mr.. Markley was the negociatvr." Let us hear Mr..
Buchanan :. ] called upon Gen. Jackson, on the
occasion which have mentioned, solely as has friend
upon my individual responsibility, and not as the
agent of MIR. Clay, or any OTHER PERSON"
Now if Mr.. Markley ncgocidted, he must have ne
gociated by Mr.. buchanan and yet Mr.. Buchanan
says he was neither the Agent Of Mr.. Clay, or
any other person. and that the conception never
entered his mind that he (Jackson) believed me to
have been the agent of Mr.. Clay, or his friends, or
that had intended to propose to him terms OF any
kind for them," and that had he 'ever known or
even suspected that Gen. Jackson believed he had
been sent to him by Mr.. Clay or his friends, he
:, should have Immediately corrected his erroneous
| impression !" and that he "had no authority from
Mr.. Clay or his friends to propose any terms in re-
lation to their votes, nor did he make any such
: proposition"


PRAY, reader, can you now tell me how this nego
i citation was carried on Mr.. Buchanan says he hat
r no hand in the matter. If Gen. Eaton to believed
It when he says that Mr.. Markey, negotiated he mus
# have negotiated the business between Messrs. Cla
and Buchanan, and the latter gentleman must hav
. laid the proposition before the Generel. Now, Mr.
. Buchanan, as we have seen, Denies over and owe
d again, that he was either the agent OF Mr.. Clay


any other person, or that he submitted to the Genera
# apy proposon on the behalf of MIR. Clay or hi
!, friends. Mr.. Eaton and MIR. Buchanan, therefore
E, are at points on this subject. Eaton says, virtually
v that Buchanan was, and that Buchanan says he wa


not an agent. So it goes.nd so let 1t go, 1t benz
!. purely Jackson affair altogether.


n We cannot however, refrain from making on
r more remark. It'll on record that DR.. Drake.
Of man of honour and high character, esttes that MI
III CLAW had determined to vote for Mr.. Adams severe


months before the election, and g that Mr.. Clay
as opinion has been coniided to several gentlemen
whose evidence when necessary, will leave no loo
at to hang doubt upon"


= GOV. KENT AND GENERAL SAUNDERS
- In the month of May last, Gov. Kent of Marylar
! wrote letter to a private gentleman, an old Col
,;r gressional friend in Kentucky, and stated that Ge


Saunders of North Carolina, in Congress during tt
. presidential election, came to him, not ten minute
f before the election, and sad 81 hope T. God you m;


be able 10 terminate the election on the tirst balie


for fear we from North Carolina may be forced


vote for Gen. Jackson The letter OF Gov. he


was not designed for publication but 1t has appea
- ed in print, and in this among other papers, Ge
~. Saunders Auq 90. has given the 6 lie direct


this statement and Gov. Kent, Oct. T. has ''thro'
on back upon Gen. Saunders the vulgar ephet.
me The National lntellgcncer states that if GeneI

Whoever has been in the practice of reading the
maniestos Of the Opposition, whether In the shape
of letters, speeches, editorial remarks, must have
noticed the repeated references made to the con-
trolling influence of the people over their public
servants, whether in high Executive offices, or IN
the National or State Legislatures. Every one will
recoect the abuse lavished on Mr.. Clay, on the
bare resumpion-conciusively put down by the
majority given to Judge Clarke, his successor-that
he in giving his vote for Mr. Adams, went against
the opinions Of his District. Most of have seen
the address of some of the friends of Gen. Jack
son in Pennsylvania. requesting Mr.. Marks. one
of the United States Senators from that State, to
resign his situation, because he will not go with that
party and they, therefore, regard him as violating
his constitutional obligations. 1t is evident, then,
that the Jackson party hold the opinion that sena-
tors in Congress ought to resign their situations, ra-
ther than give their votes and influence In oppose
ton to the feelings and wishes Of their several
States.


| The result in the elections in Delaware, must
have satisfied every that this State IS decidedly
| in favour of the measures Of the present Admins
tration, and the reelection of Mr.. Adams. The
question has been distinctly put to them, at the
polls-. Will you elect Representative to Con-
nress who will bindly follow the steps of those who
oppose the Administration and support Gen. jack
son or will you choose one who will take the oppo-
site course. supporting the Administration and op-
posing General Jackson ?" Their answer IS ex-
pilici and decided. They have declared their con-
fdence in the Administration, and their want Ut
confidence in Gen. Jackson.


Now what is the obvious course for the two Sena-
TORS from Delaware to pursue, according, not to he


theory only, but to the practice OF the jackson par
/ ty hey must support the Administration il the,


represent the feelings and wishes Of the State if


not. ought not they ALSO according TO the doctrines
Of the Opposition, to be called on to resign and to
make loom for such as will be the faithful organs Of


public opinion in Delaware?

JOHN SERGEANT, Esq. a decided friend cf the
Administration was elected member to Congress,
on Tuesday last, in Philadelphia. His opponent
was Joseph Hemphill Esq. decided Jacksonian.
Mr. Scrgeants majority was l56 votes.

DELAWARE JOURNAL.

Friday, October AZ, AS21.
full articles.article:
As specimen Of the meetings. now holding in
Virginia, in opposition to General Jackson, we lay
before our readers those of Spotsylyania.

/. The General, in his Carter Beverly letter,
above quoted, makes it g early IN January 1895 !"
and in his Address to the Public, dated July, 10,
1927, he makes it in January 1885, rather more
safe period Of time, though not quite so precise.


g. Mr.. Buchanan, from letters which he wrote on
three days, Dec. 30, and 81 1924, and January 2,
1926, which letters he has probably since seen,
s' fixes the time" of his conversation on the Hirtleth
day Of December, 1924.


3. Mr.. Eatonsays that Mr. Buchanan talked with
him on the 9Th or 10Th Of Jam 1925, and then had
his interview with the General on the snext day
viz. on the 9th or Goth.


Now here seems to be some little difference be-
tween the " 30h December, 1894, early in JAN
uary," 'sn January" and the g 9th or Goth jan
uary 1926" Who's right and whose wrong
Mr.. Buchanan declares that he had but one con-
versation, prior to the election, and we have seen
three several periods mentioned at which it took
place, with difference of three weeks between the
time specified by Mr.. Buchanan and Mr.. Eaton
Both are quite sure as to the time, but both cannot
be right.


If there are such errors as to time, when one
fixes the precise day, another makes it early and
then sem January, and another the 18th OF goth
January, 1895, it is not difficult to believe that in
their statements there are


Some other differences.


Let us see. Mr. Eaton says BY the showing of
Mr.. lsaacks and Mr. Buchanan, it now appears, that
Mr.. Markley was the negociatvr." Let us hear Mr..
Buchanan :. ] called upon Gen. Jackson, on the
occasion which have mentioned, solely as has friend
upon my individual responsibility, and not as the
agent of MIR. Clay, or any OTHER PERSON"
Now if Mr.. Markley ncgocidted, he must have ne
gociated by Mr.. buchanan and yet Mr.. Buchanan
says he was neither the Agent Of Mr.. Clay, or
any other person. and that the conception never
entered his mind that he (Jackson) believed me to
have been the agent of Mr.. Clay, or his friends, or
that had intended to propose to him terms OF any
kind for them," and that had he 'ever known or
even suspected that Gen. Jackson believed he had
been sent to him by Mr.. Clay or his friends, he
:, should have Immediately corrected his erroneous
| impression !" and that he "had no authority from
Mr.. Clay or his friends to propose any terms in re-
lation to their votes, nor did he make any such
: proposition"


PRAY, reader, can you now tell me how this nego
i citation was carried on Mr.. Buchanan says he hat
r no hand in the matter. If Gen. Eaton to believed
It when he says that Mr.. Markey, negotiated he mus
# have negotiated the business between Messrs. Cla
and Buchanan, and the latter gentleman must hav
. laid the proposition before the Generel. Now, Mr.
. Buchanan, as we have seen, Denies over and owe
d again, that he was either the agent OF Mr.. Clay


any other person, or that he submitted to the Genera
# apy proposon on the behalf of MIR. Clay or hi
!, friends. Mr.. Eaton and MIR. Buchanan, therefore
E, are at points on this subject. Eaton says, virtually
v that Buchanan was, and that Buchanan says he wa


not an agent. So it goes.nd so let 1t go, 1t benz
!. purely Jackson affair altogether.


n We cannot however, refrain from making on
r more remark. It'll on record that DR.. Drake.
Of man of honour and high character, esttes that MI
III CLAW had determined to vote for Mr.. Adams severe


months before the election, and g that Mr.. Clay
as opinion has been coniided to several gentlemen
whose evidence when necessary, will leave no loo
at to hang doubt upon"


= GOV. KENT AND GENERAL SAUNDERS
- In the month of May last, Gov. Kent of Marylar
! wrote letter to a private gentleman, an old Col
,;r gressional friend in Kentucky, and stated that Ge


Saunders of North Carolina, in Congress during tt
. presidential election, came to him, not ten minute
f before the election, and sad 81 hope T. God you m;


be able 10 terminate the election on the tirst balie


for fear we from North Carolina may be forced


vote for Gen. Jackson The letter OF Gov. he


was not designed for publication but 1t has appea
- ed in print, and in this among other papers, Ge
~. Saunders Auq 90. has given the 6 lie direct


this statement and Gov. Kent, Oct. T. has ''thro'
on back upon Gen. Saunders the vulgar ephet.
me The National lntellgcncer states that if GeneI

full articles.headline: From the National Melkgencer.
full articles.article:
Whoever has been in the practice of reading the
maniestos Of the Opposition, whether In the shape
of letters, speeches, editorial remarks, must have
noticed the repeated references made to the con-
trolling influence of the people over their public
servants, whether in high Executive offices, or IN
the National or State Legislatures. Every one will
recoect the abuse lavished on Mr.. Clay, on the
bare resumpion-conciusively put down by the
majority given to Judge Clarke, his successor-that
he in giving his vote for Mr. Adams, went against
the opinions Of his District. Most of have seen
the address of some of the friends of Gen. Jack
son in Pennsylvania. requesting Mr.. Marks. one
of the United States Senators from that State, to
resign his situation, because he will not go with that
party and they, therefore, regard him as violating
his constitutional obligations. 1t is evident, then,
that the Jackson party hold the opinion that sena-
tors in Congress ought to resign their situations, ra-
ther than give their votes and influence In oppose
ton to the feelings and wishes Of their several
States.


| The result in the elections in Delaware, must
have satisfied every that this State IS decidedly
| in favour of the measures Of the present Admins
tration, and the reelection of Mr.. Adams. The
question has been distinctly put to them, at the
polls-. Will you elect Representative to Con-
nress who will bindly follow the steps of those who
oppose the Administration and support Gen. jack
son or will you choose one who will take the oppo-
site course. supporting the Administration and op-
posing General Jackson ?" Their answer IS ex-
pilici and decided. They have declared their con-
fdence in the Administration, and their want Ut
confidence in Gen. Jackson.


Now what is the obvious course for the two Sena-
TORS from Delaware to pursue, according, not to he


theory only, but to the practice OF the jackson par
/ ty hey must support the Administration il the,


represent the feelings and wishes Of the State if


not. ought not they ALSO according TO the doctrines
Of the Opposition, to be called on to resign and to
make loom for such as will be the faithful organs Of


public opinion in Delaware?

THE Greeks-Letters from COnstantinople OF the

Greece, whatever may be the repugnance OF the 60
